comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Is that where e used to go when he was mitching;-). I doubt he can see his school from that one?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Thank you! And yes, I'm sure this is the iron footbridge at Farrenboley National School, crossing the Harcourt Street railway line from Lower Churchtown Road to Columbanus Road.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: Would that be Taney National School and, of course, that's the Harcourt Street line. A sister-in-law of mine taught in that school. That line has always fascinated me. It's good the line was preserved or we wouldn't have the LUAS Green Line. I could tell a story about that school, the disused line, a set of car keys and a naughty pupil but daren't :D

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Oi! I didn't where I am today by mitching off school! Here is the same bridge in 1994, in bits: This is now the site of Windy Arbour Station on the Luas green line.

comment._content: Yes, this is looking past where Windy Arbour station is now towards town,

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This bridge was not as old as some which still survive. The bridge at Clonsilla is from 1850, but this one is not on the 1907 OSI 25" map. It may only date from the 1950's, when the houses in Farrenboley and Our Lady's National School were built here.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] So, then it would have been pretty new when James O'Dea took this photograph at the start of 1959...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yes, although the line was already closed by then!

It may have only been in proper use, crossing an active railway line, for less than 10 years. The line closed at the end of 1958, the rails were lifted during 1959.

The bridge remained in use for some time after that, until a pathway was built straight across where the footpath crosses the Luas line today, and the entrances to the bridge were bricked up.

The footpath would cross about where the fence on the right ends beyond the bridge in this picture.
